image.altText: A man and woman walk together outside a building. He wears a collared shirt and trousers.

props.synopsis: The former shop assistant admitted to slapping his young coworker on the bottom if he saw her working in the shop, when she was stacking shelves or checking inventory, or her back was turned and she did not see him coming.

title.children: Queanbeyan man avoids jail for repeatedly sexually touching teenage coworker

image.altText: A sign reading "Look out Swooping bird'' with a picture of a magpie, in front of a road.

props.synopsis: Magpie nesting season is in full swing and wildlife experts want walkers and cyclists to know how best to respond to swooping birds.

title.children: 'They remember faces': What you should and shouldn't do when a magpie swoops

image.altText: Two men on bicylces strike each other with sticks.

props.synopsis: Every four years, members of the Rat Patrol mount their home-made "freak bikes" and take to Canberra's drains to compete in the Rat'lympics.

title.children: These 'human rats' search high and low for the perfect discarded parts to make their mutant bikes

image.altText: A bird's eye view of a leafy suburb full of houses.

props.synopsis: Creating a housing policy that satisfies everyone is nearly impossible, but each ACT party leader is promoting their credentials as a Goldilocks, arguing that their housing porridge is neither too hot nor too cold.

title.children: Striking the perfect housing policy balance is tricky, but pulling it off could be key to winning the ACT election

image.altText: A small white dog wearing a green knitted jacket and sitting on a grey couch.

props.synopsis: NSW Premier Chris Minns said he hoped the bill, which will be introduced to parliament next month, would "make things a bit less stressful for renters".

title.children: Renters with pets big winners in NSW government shake-up

image.altText: A young man and a woman wearing caps and life vests stand on a jetty.

props.synopsis: Volunteers are Australia's invisible workforce … but many organisations are facing a reckoning as community stalwarts get older and are forced to take a step back.

title.children: Jess and Basil are bucking a troubling trend by giving their time for free

image.altText: An aerial view of Melbourne's south-eastern suburbs.

props.synopsis: The RBA is meeting today to hand down this year's sixth cash rate decision, but only one of Australia's four major banks expects a rate cut by the end of the year.

title.children: Hoping the RBA will cut interest rates today? Here's what the big four banks are saying

image.altText: Two 'land girls' with a furrow in 1942.

props.synopsis: As recently as the 1990s many women still avoided the f-word, hesitating to call themselves farmers in a world that overlooked their contribution to agriculture.

title.children: It's been 30 years since the census recognised women as farmers, but there's still 'a long way to go'

image.altText: Smoke plumes coming out of a city scape.

props.synopsis: Israel's military has launched more than 800 strikes on Lebanon targeting Hezbollah after warning residents to leave areas where the terrorist group may be operating. Follow live.

title.children: Thousands flee Israeli strikes in Lebanon's deadliest day since civil war

image.altText: A view of the Reserve Bank of Australia with people walking by.

props.synopsis: Central banks, including the RBA, subscribe to an old economics theory that unemployment must rise in order for inflation to fall. It's one they should consign to the dustbin.

title.children: RBA relying on outdated theory about inflation and employment

image.altText: Four men and one woman stand handcuffed in front of a table with guns on it

props.synopsis: South-East Asian politicians have called for the unconditional release of five democracy activists whose executions are imminent.

title.children: 'Unspeakable acts by an unspeakable regime': Myanmar democracy activists to be executed

image.altText: A woman in a World Central Kitchen shirt smiles at the camera standing in a cafe

props.synopsis: Foreign Minister Penny Wong will call for a new international declaration for the protection of humanitarian personnel following the killing of Australian aid worker Zomi Frankcom in Gaza earlier this year.

title.children: Australia to push world leaders to better protect aid workers after Zomi Frankcom's death in Gaza

image.altText: A middle-aged Kurdish woman smiles at the camera in a posed but informal portrait shot.

props.synopsis: Cigdem Aslan, whose Australian passport is in the name of Lenna Aslan, was reportedly arrested at Istanbul Airport on suspicion of conducting activities for the PKK, a banned terrorist group in both Türkiye and Australia.

title.children: Australian woman arrested in Türkiye on suspicion of supporting banned Kurdish terror group

image.altText: A man with a world map behind him

props.synopsis: The man accused of hiding out with a gun near Donald Trump's Florida golf course in an apparent bid to kill the former president wrote a letter months earlier describing an "assassination attempt", prosecutors say.

title.children: Ryan Routh wrote letter describing 'assassination attempt' on Trump, prosecutors say

image.altText: A man speaks at a lectern

props.synopsis: Climate Change Authority head Matt Kean says expert advice differs to what Peter Dutton says about nuclear and renewables being companions not competitors.

title.children: 'Very different advice': Climate Change Authority chair Matt Kean contradicts Dutton on nuclear power

image.altText: Lachlan Murdoch stands at a lectern to give a speech. An image of a US flag is on a screen behind him.

props.synopsis: Rupert Murdoch's court battle with his children is about more than money. He's fighting to keep his media empire conservative

title.children: 'The day Rupert dies is the day Lachlan gets fired': The words that rocked the Murdoch empire

image.altText: Peter Dutton speaking publicly outdoors, wearing a suit with a yellow ribbon pinned on the lapel.

props.synopsis: Opposition leader Peter Dutton has said he would abolish the position of Ambassador for First Nations People on "day one" if elected, describing it as a "waste of taxpayer money".

title.children: Dutton vows to scrap new First Nations ambassador position if elected

image.altText: A banner reading 'Coles' and, in the background, the Woolworths logo.

props.synopsis: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission launches legal action against Woolworths and Coles, alleging the supermarket giants breached consumer law by misleading consumers through discount pricing claims on hundreds of products.

title.children: 'The conduct we are considering is very serious': ACCC launches action against Coles and Woolworths

image.altText: A man is pictured from behind.

props.synopsis: The credibility of the Albanese government's much vaunted wagering self-exclusion scheme BetStop has been called into question after loopholes in the system allowed a Sydney man to lose nearly $70,000 despite signing up to a lifetime ban.

title.children: BetStop was supposed to protect gambling addicts like Ravi, but it didn't stop him from losing nearly $70,000

image.altText: Colin Kinner, who has short brown hair and is wearing a blue collared shirt, poses for a photo next to a window

props.synopsis: A free online course aims to bust COVID misinformation and teach people how to stop the virus spreading in schools. But perhaps its greatest challenge is engaging people in the first place — particularly those who believe COVID is harmless.

title.children: An Australian dad is on a mission to get schools to take COVID more seriously

image.altText: An illustration of a man dreaming of sleep-tracking wearables

props.synopsis: Sleep-tracking has boomed in popularity worldwide, giving researchers access to millions of hours of sleep data. When a natural disaster hits or a COVID variant spreads, they see the impact in our sleep.

title.children: ‘The whole world is becoming a sleep laboratory': The rise and rise of sleep-tracking devices

image.altText: Donald Trump holds up a fist. A crowd is behind him.

props.synopsis: Former president Donald Trump says that he will not make a fourth consecutive run for the US presidency if he loses the upcoming election.

title.children: 'That will be it': Trump says he will not run again if he loses in November

image.altText: Rose Staleo

props.synopsis: The banking royal commission described the way in which mortgage brokers are paid as "conflicted remuneration" and "money for nothing". Customers don't care.

title.children: Three in four home loans are written by mortgage brokers, infuriating banks and delighting customers

image.altText: New Socceroos coach Tony Popovic sits a desk and answers questions from the media.

props.synopsis: Tony Popovic has been named the new head coach of the Socceroos, taking over after the sudden resignation of Graham Arnold.

title.children: Popovic named as new Socceroos coach ahead of crucial World Cup qualifiers

image.altText: Daniel Ricciardo wipes his face

props.synopsis: Daniel Ricciardo may well have turned his final corner in a F1 car after an emotional interview following the Singapore Grand Prix.

title.children: Tearful Daniel Ricciardo 'aware it could be it' for his F1 career

image.altText: Patrick Cripps kisses the Brownlow Medal on stage

props.synopsis: Carlton captain Patrick Cripps takes home his second Brownlow Medal, breaking the record for most votes received in a single AFL season in the process.

title.children: Patrick Cripps claims his second Brownlow with record-breaking vote tally

image.altText: Side view close-up of pregnant woman touching her belly

props.synopsis: People who want to terminate their pregnancy after 28 weeks could be required to instead deliver their baby alive under proposed changes to laws in South Australia that decriminalised abortion three years ago.

title.children: MP pushes for births over abortions in proposed SA law changes

image.altText: Hobart bus mall in Elizabeth Street

props.synopsis: Tasmania is to finally get a 'smart' ticketing system for the state's bus and ferry network at a cost of $35.4 million.

title.children: Tasmania promises 'smart' public transport payment usually reserved for major cities

image.altText: A close up side-on shot of a brown baby penguin.

props.synopsis: At just nine months of age, Pesto is already far bigger than the adult king penguins at Melbourne's aquarium.

title.children: Inside the pen with Pesto, the Melbourne aquarium's super-sized penguin

image.altText: Anthony Albanese, Narenda Modi, Joe Biden and Fumio Kishida stand in a line next to each other.

props.synopsis: Here's four things Anthony Albanese's trip revealed about the Quad, leadership, language and life lessons.

title.children: Four takeaways from the prime minister's 48 hours in the US for the Quad

image.altText: Ben Zygier

props.synopsis: A new documentary aims to shed more light on the case of Prisoner X, who was identified as Australian man Ben Zygier. He'd been working as a spy for Mossad but his alleged crimes remain shrouded in secrecy.

title.children: How the man known as 'Prisoner X' went from suburban Melbourne to the heart of Mossad

image.altText: A concept image for Hobart's Macquarie Point stadium.

props.synopsis: A three-storey, underground car park at Hobart's proposed Macquarie Point AFL stadium is the latest known exclusion from the building cost estimates, a parliamentary hearing is told.

title.children: More items revealed as not being budgeted for in Hobart's proposed stadium costings

image.altText: A man on a stage grasps his hands, while listening to someone

props.synopsis: Pony Ma's resurgence might seem like a positive signal of a more permissive market environment. But as we watch China's private sector grow, we should remember it follows China's unique playbook.

title.children: Are things looking up for China's tech billionaires?

image.altText: A crowd sits on sandy banks

props.synopsis: More than 2,500 people attended the six-day event's finale, set in the natural amphitheatre of Ormiston Gorge, Kwartatuma.

title.children: Curtain call for Desert Song Festival with director citing need for more arts funding
